subject: Call mobiles and landlines free for a month
body:
Get your free month »  
 Can't see this email properly? Forgotten your password? 
 
 

Free worldwide calls to mobiles and landlines1 for a month

We'd like to give you unlimited2 calling free for a month (worth $13.99)3. So, on top of your usual free Skype to Skype calls, you can also call friends and family on their mobile or landlines.
 
With a Skype Unlimited2
World subscription, you get:
Get your free month
 
 
 
Unlimited2 calls to landlines in 63 countries/regions and mobiles in 8 countries/regions
No commitment. You can cancel at any time4
Call when you want - any day, any time
An easy way to call from your mobile, tablet, laptop, or TV5, all from the familiar Skype app
 
 
 
Love calling with Skype Unlimited2 World!
Get your free month
 
Access
 my account 		Download
 latest version 		Explore
 Skype features 		Questions?
 We can help
﻿
 
  Unlimited World subscription includes

Calls to both landlines and mobiles in: Canada, China, Guam, Hong Kong SAR, Puerto Rico, Singapore, Thailand and United States

Calls to only landlines in: Andorra, Argentina, Australia, Austria, Belgium, Brazil, Brunei, Bulgaria, Chile, Colombia (excluding rural areas - LEX), Costa Rica, Croatia, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Guadeloupe, Hungary, Iceland, Indonesia (Jakarta only), Republic of Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan, Korea, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malaysia, Malta, Mexico, Morocco, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Russia, Slovakia, Slovenia, South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Taiwan, Turkey, United Kingdom, and Venezuela.

Subscription excludes special, premium and non-geographic numbers.

1 Offer comprises a one (1) month "Unlimited World" subscription. Subscription commences on redemption date. Only one free trial Skype Unlimited World subscription can be claimed per customer. Broadband Internet required; ISP and/or mobile carrier fees may apply. Skype's Terms of Use apply. To qualify for the offer, you must have or create a Skype account and provide valid payment details. Your first month is completely free, and unless you cancel your subscription within 27 days from the start of your free trial, your subscription will automatically continue and an amount of $13.99 will be automatically charged to your payment card at the end of your free trial and every subsequent subscription term.

Terms can change without notice at any time. No cash redemption, except where required by law. Offer subject to availability. Skype reserves the right to withdraw this offer at any time and to deny and/or disregard any offer request deemed in Skype’s sole discretion to be false, fraudulent, or ineligible.

subject: March Newsletter
body:
Kazuo Ishiguro, Erik Larson, Mary Doria Russell, Lynne Truss, Ian Caldwell, and tons of new books! Find your next great read!

View this email in your browser
http://www.goodreads.com/newsletter/show/march2015?utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=view_in_browser&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter

  SPONSORED BY
  http://www.goodreads.com/track/daily_click?target=_blank&tid=US_PatriotThreatNLMar_4800_textonly&url=http%3A%2F%2Fsteveberry.org%2Fbooks%2Fthe-patriot-threat%2Fsynopsis%2F%3Futm_source%3Dgoodreads%26utm_medium%3DBannerAdAnimated%26utm_term%3D596by74newslettermainsponsor%26utm_content%3D-na_read_buynow%26utm_campaign%3D9781250056238&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter

Hi  Yoel,

Here's our monthly newsletter from Goodreads - giving you the latest and greatest in our quest to help you find your next favorite book!





EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEWS

Kazuo Ishiguro
An elderly couple eludes ogres, dragons, and peculiar memory loss on a journey through medieval Britain in The Buried Giant, new from the author of Never Let Me Go.
https://www.goodreads.com/interviews/show/1015.Kazuo_Ishiguro?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=ishiguro

Erik Larson
The narrative nonfiction master mixes political intrigue and personal tragedy in Dead Wake, an account of the shocking 1915 sinking of the British luxury liner Lusitania.
https://www.goodreads.com/interviews/show/1014.Erik_Larson?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=larson

BOOK LOOK
At Large: Ai Weiwei on Alcatraz
https://www.goodreads.com/book_news_posts/164-at-large-ai-weiwei-on-alcatraz?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=booklook

GOOD MINDS SUGGEST
Mary Doria Russell's Favorite Westerns
Not just for gunslingers, the real Wild West comes to life in these five frontier tales recommended by the author of Epitaph.
https://www.goodreads.com/interviews/show/1018.Mary_Doria_Russell?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=russell

Ian Caldwell's Favorite Books About Vatican Crime
Murder, greed, and conspiracy in the Holy See—try these recs from the suspense writer whose latest thrill ride is The Fifth Gospel.
https://www.goodreads.com/interviews/show/1017.Ian_Caldwell?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=caldwell

Lynne Truss's Favorite Clever Literary Cats
From the grammarian who wrote Eats, Shoots & Leaves comes new comic horror, Cat Out of Hell. She offers a feline top five.
https://www.goodreads.com/interviews/show/1016.Lynne_Truss?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=truss

DEBUT AUTHOR SNAPSHOT
Claire Fuller
Kidnapped at age eight, Peggy lives in the woods, believing that she and her dad are the only two people left alive in the world in the new novel Our Endless Numbered Days.
https://www.goodreads.com/interviews/show/1019.Claire_Fuller?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=fuller


BEST BOOKS OF THE MONTH
Delicious Foods
by James Hannaham (Goodreads Author)
Narrated in part by the seductive voice of crack cocaine, this unorthodox novel tells the grim story of a young black man with amputated hands searching for his mother, the victim of human trafficking.
https://www.goodreads.com/featured_lists/143-best-books-of-the-month---march-2015?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=botm1


Life from Scratch
by Sasha Martin (Goodreads Author)
Eat your way around the world with Martin, who decided to learn how to cook a meal from every country on earth (that's 195 countries!). Her culinary memoir also shares how her love of food was forged by a difficult childhood.
https://www.goodreads.com/featured_lists/143-best-books-of-the-month---march-2015?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=botm2

Life or Death
by Michael Robotham (Goodreads Author)
Just one day before the end of his ten-year sentence, felon Audie Palmer escapes from a Texas prison in this action-packed thriller. Is he chasing the $7 million from his botched robbery or is there a different agenda afoot?
https://www.goodreads.com/featured_lists/143-best-books-of-the-month---march-2015?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=botm3

Better Than Before: Mastering the Habits of Our Everyday Lives
by Gretchen Rubin (Goodreads Author)
Are you an upholder, questioner, obliger, or rebel? The author of The Happiness Project breaks down how habits form and why they are so hard to break based on four personality types in this practical self-help tome.
https://www.goodreads.com/featured_lists/143-best-books-of-the-month---march-2015?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=botm4

A Little Life
by Hanya Yanagihara (Goodreads Author)
An immersive character study, this literary novel follows three decades of highs and lows experienced by a quartet of friends—a painter, an actor, an architect, and a troubled lawyer—each making their way in New York City.
https://www.goodreads.com/featured_lists/143-best-books-of-the-month---march-2015?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=botm5

Under a Painted Sky
by Stacey Lee (Goodreads Author)
1849, Missouri: On the run from the law, Samantha and Annamae disguise themsleves as boys, head west on the Oregon Trail, and encounter plenty of danger, adventure, and cowboys in this historical novel for teens.
https://www.goodreads.com/featured_lists/143-best-books-of-the-month---march-2015?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=botm6

DO GOOD WITH GOODREADS
The Book Bus
Honk honk! Here comes the Book Bus! Find out how you can help this nonprofit bring books to underserved children in Zambia, Malawi, Ecuador, and beyond.
https://www.goodreads.com/book_news_posts/163-the-book-bus?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=dogood


GOODREADS POETRY CONTEST
http://www.goodreads.com/group/show/233._POETRY_?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-02&utm_content=poetry

Want your words to reach millions of people? Goodreads and the ¡POETRY! group have partnered to host an ongoing poetry contest. Join the POETRY! group and vote each month to pick a winner from among the finalists.You can also submit a poem for consideration. Here is our March winner!

What We Talk About When We Talk About Love
by John Jeffire (Goodreads Author)
https://www.goodreads.com/story/show/394447-what-we-talk-about-when-we-talk-about-love?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=poetry
https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/940357.John_Jeffire?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=poetry


So many ways of looking
At a blackbird tossed
In the autumn sky.
From the dry shadows
Of the bed from which
The sun cannot step,
Your whisper flits above:
I am free to leave.
First, a living will,
Power of attorney,
No machines or tubes,
We first discussed this
When our hearts beat quick
In the raven's glimmer,
A clatter of wings burst
At red clay and live oak—
Free to go. But I have
No southern stomach.
I wipe feces from crevices
My tongue once explored,
I scrape uneaten meals
From cracked plates,
I dig arms under whatever
Is left to dig under—
So many ways of looking
At a blackbird thrown
In an autumn sky, life alit
In the few uncollapsed rivers
Of your hands, and I consider
The offer, freedom, mine from
You or yours from me not clear.
Stand with me, survey the distance:
Blanched earth, seedless,
Scab stubble frozen pools,
Creek frozen in its sheets,
The only proof of life its absence:
The bank gives way beneath our feet,
I grip the crest of your waist,
And one wing between us,
We take flight.


Read More Poetry
http://www.goodreads.com/story/genre/19.Poetry?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-03&utm_content=poetry

subject: Testing, testing. One, Two

subject: An update on your first week of brain training:
body:
Hi yoel, learn about your Fit Test results

Just over a week ago, you took the Fit Test. Compared to your age group, you performed best in Memory Matrix.
This game challenged your spatial recall, or your memory for locations and positions in your environment.

How Memory Matrix challenges your brain


Games like Memory Matrix challenge you to use your visuospatial sketchpad — a concept from psychologist Alan Baddeley’s model for working memory. Associated with several parts your brain, this important tool stores visual information, like color or shape, and spatial information, like location.

When you memorize the location of tiles in Memory Matrix, your visuospatial sketchpad stores their location, and maybe even the shapes they create. When the tiles disappear, your neurons continue firing in the same pattern as when you saw them — allowing you to remember where the tiles are.


Stay challenged with more games

You’re off to a great start in your brain training journey. But staying challenged means playing a wide variety of games that challenge many cognitive abilities, like Attention, Problem Solving, and more.

If you’re ready to push yourself further, subscribe to Lumosity Premium and play 40+ games that challenge all of these important abilities.

subject: How the brain learns:
body:
How the brain learns:

Can brain research help us become better learners? As we gain a deeper understanding of how the brain learns, neuroscientists are eager to apply brain research in the classroom and beyond. Here are a few key research insights to try next time you learn something new.

Learning means new connections in the brain

Your brain works like an electrical circuit. Every time you learn something new, connections form between neurons in your brain. Just as an electrical current travels through a circuit, signals are transmitted from one group of neurons to another.
 
If you’re learning the name of a new coworker, for example, signals travel between facial recognition neurons and auditory neurons (that process her name). The next time you pass that coworker in the hallway, those same groups of neurons will fire as you recall her name.
 
Researchers can measure the strength of these neural connections through a technique called electrophysiology. In this procedure, scientists insert microelectrodes into specific regions of the brain, and measure the electric current transmitted between groups of neurons. The stronger the current, the stronger the connection between the neurons.
 
If you have a daily ritual, you’re felt the effects of a strong connection. Hopping in your car, turning the key in the ignition, and backing out of your driveway can all happen without you even thinking about it. This feeling of automaticity is a result of brain circuitry that’s been strengthened through repetition.

More connections mean more effective learning

Just as the strength of neural connections plays a role in learning, so does the quantity of connections.
 
What’s the most effective way to learn a new piece of information, such as a license plate number, or a friend’s birthday? An isolated fact can be tough to remember, but you can make it easier for yourself by relating new facts to other networks of information.
 
Say you need to memorize that Benjamin Franklin was born in January 1706. Perhaps you can remember January because he had white hair, like snow in January. You can remember 1706 because you live at 170 Main Street, and you take the #6 bus to get to work.
 
You will be more likely to remember Benjamin Franklin’s birthdate now that you’ve formed connections across multiple neural systems. You’ll have a more robust network of connections for recalling this information later.
 
Now that you’ve read a bit about the brain research behind learning, try applying it the next time you learn a new fact.

subject: May Newsletter
body:
Toni Morrison, David McCullough, Clive Barker, Paolo Bacigalupi, and tons of new books! Find your next great read!

View this email in your browser:
https://www.goodreads.com/newsletter/show/may2015?utm_campaign=2015-05&utm_content=view_in_browser_text&utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter

Hi Yoel,

Here's our monthly newsletter from Goodreads - giving you the latest and greatest in our quest to help you find your next favorite book!


EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEWS

Toni Morrison
The celebrated author of Beloved talks about her latest novel, the taut and unflinching God Help the Child, the business of color in modern America, and why she has to write.
https://www.goodreads.com/interviews/show/1029.Toni_Morrison?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-05&utm_content=morrison_text

David McCullough
The two-time Pulitzer winner chronicles the daredevil ingenuity of two bicycle mechanics destined for greatness in his new work of narrative history, The Wright Brothers.
https://www.goodreads.com/interviews/show/1028.David_McCullough?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-05&utm_content=mccullough_text


BOOK LOOK

Balancing Acts: Three Prima Ballerinas Becoming Mothers
https://www.goodreads.com/book_news_posts/168-balancing-acts-three-prima-ballerinas-becoming-mothers?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-05&utm_content=booklook_text


GOOD MINDS SUGGEST

Clive Barker's Favorite Books About Good vs. Evil
The master of supernatural gore offers a hell-raising top five in honor of his new work of horror, The Scarlet Gospels.
https://www.goodreads.com/interviews/show/1032.Clive_Barker?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-05&utm_content=barker_text

Paolo Bacigalupi's Favorite Books About the Future
Water is scarce in his sci-fi thriller, The Water Knife, which peers into our possible future, along with these five recs.
https://www.goodreads.com/interviews/show/1031.Paolo_Bacigalupi?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-05&utm_content=bacigalupi_text


DEBUT AUTHOR SNAPSHOT
Sarai Walker
Both a subversive feminist journey and an immersive character study--and definitely not a book about dieting--the new novel Dietland packs a surprising punch.
https://www.goodreads.com/interviews/show/1030.Sarai_Walker?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-05&utm_content=walker_text


BEST BOOKS OF THE MONTH
Girl at War
by Sara Nović (Goodreads Author)
A child in a battle zone, ten-year-old Ana navigates the streets of 1991 Zagreb as Croatia erupts in war. This haunting literary novel bears witness to her violent coming-of-age and, later, her struggles as a student in New York.
https://www.goodreads.com/featured_lists/162-best-books-of-the-month-may-2015?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-05&utm_content=botm1_text

The Soul of an Octopus
by Sy Montgomery
How does an octopus think or feel? In this nonfiction account, naturalist Sy Montgomery describes her special friendships with octopuses, including one sweet and intelligent animal named Athena.
https://www.goodreads.com/featured_lists/162-best-books-of-the-month-may-2015?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-05&utm_content=botm2_text

Little Black Lies
by Sharon Bolton (Goodreads Author)
A marine biologist plotting murder. Her best friend racked with guilt. An insular community seeking justice for a missing child. This dark thriller, set on the remote Falkland Islands, asks, How far would you go for revenge?
https://www.goodreads.com/featured_lists/162-best-books-of-the-month-may-2015?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-05&utm_content=botm3_text

The Ingenious Mr. Pyke: Inventor, Fugitive, Spy
by Henry Hemming (Goodreads Author)
This rollicking biography tells the life story of an unsung genius. A British journalist who escaped the Germans during WWI, Geoffrey Pyke became a military adviser famous for his zany ideas...and possibly a Soviet spy.
https://www.goodreads.com/featured_lists/162-best-books-of-the-month-may-2015?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-05&utm_content=botm4_text

The Mapmaker's Children
by Sarah McCoy (Goodreads Author)
After another miscarriage, Eden investigates a porcelain doll head she finds in her new house, a clue that links her to the incredible true story of Sarah Brown, a mapmaker for the Underground Railroad whose life is told in parallel.
https://www.goodreads.com/featured_lists/162-best-books-of-the-month-may-2015?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-05&utm_content=botm5_text

A Court of Thorns and Roses
by Sarah J. Maas (Goodreads Author)
Humans and faeries live apart in this epic fantasy for teens. When a young huntress is taken to the faerie kingdom as payment for a blood debt, she grows close to her beastly captor but learns that a coming evil threatens all faerie life.
https://www.goodreads.com/featured_lists/162-best-books-of-the-month-may-2015?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-05&utm_content=botm6_text


DO GOOD WITH GOODREADS
The Rocky Mountain Land Library
Imagine a peaceful spot to read, surrounded by books and sweeping alpine views--a nature-loving bibliophile's dream! Find out how you can support a library in the making.
https://www.goodreads.com/book_news_posts/167-rocky-mountain-land-library?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-05&utm_content=dogood_text


GOODREADS POETRY CONTEST
http://www.goodreads.com/group/show/233._POETRY_?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter&utm_campaign=2015-05&utm_content=poetry_text

Want your words to reach millions of people? Goodreads and the ¡POETRY! group have partnered to host an ongoing poetry contest. Join the POETRY! group and vote each month to pick a winner from among the finalists. You can also submit a poem for consideration. Here is our May winner!

I Am Finished with Being Dead
by Jane Ellen Glasser (Goodreads Author)

Pushing through gray sheets,
the sun teases the world
into being:

a few clouds, rooftops,
a neighbor's dog
loosened into the yard,
yipping, the starting up
of engines purring
to go somewhere,
do something.

Does it really matter
what the crow in the crown
of the cherry tree
is plotting?

Black feathers in pink snow!

I remember the hours
of love's holding,
sleeping and waking--the same.
I remember the fog and the pain
of love's fumbling,
sleeping and waking--the same.

I let go, abandon dreams
of being abandoned
the way, now, the egret
sweeps white wings
across the clearing sky.

At the river's rim, a goose
tucks the black snake
of its neck
along its soft spine.

Like an eye
awake in its sleeping--
the white cheek-patch.

Like time stalling--the river
in its fullness, still.

Still in their clothes,
layered like the homeless
in everything they own,
a man and a woman
hiding inside their history.

There is no memory that can undo me!

Weightless without wanting,
a man undressing
before a woman,
a woman undressing
in the presence of a man.

There is no nakedness that can kill me!

There is only this:
the moving in and moving out
of water, of light;

the beating and the resting,
black wings, white wings--the same;

the wind breathing
into the day and the day's
receiving mouth.


With love,
The Goodreads Editorial Team
